newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX oil complex closes up, heat leading rebound.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX oil complex closes up, heat leading rebound.

text.p: The NYMEX oil complex closed up sharply after early news of a refinery fire and a pipeline shutdown sparked short covering following two days of profit-taking, traders said.
"There were several news items like the early Tosco refinery fire and the Sumed pipeline shut down that made this go up," said one trader.
October crude settled up 58 cts to $22.30 a barrel.
A fire broke out late Wednesday night at the Bayway refinery in New Jersey though its operator Tosco Corp reported little damage.
Near term resistance in September heating oil was pegged at 62.85 cts a gallon and for October crude at $22.50 a barrel. Some sources said crude's short-term gains were limited on a lack of news.
"With no bullish news, crude is going to have a hard time getting through $22.50," said Rita Beale, an analyst with Fimat USA Futures.
Traders are waiting to see what impact Tropical Storm Dolly will have on Mexico's oil operations as well as those of others in the Gulf of Mexico on Friday.
Dolly is expected to reach hurricane strength before making landfall and has since shut down Mexico's three crucial crude export ports.
Meanwhile, normal operations resumed at the Sumed pipeline in the Mediterranean after the 2.4 million barrel-a-day pipeline reported a brief shutdown.
Crude's rise also reflected a rally in September heating oil which settled up 1.50 cts to 62.48 cts a gallon on views of tight stocks.
"There was only a very slight build," said one trader of the most recent inventory data on heating oil.
September gasoline's gains lagged, closing 0.76 ct at 63.88 cts a gallon amid talk of a large amount of gasoline imports from Europe seen arriving in two weeks.
